content: Hey @T-lang design meeting today, document: https://hackmd.io/l8E3dUd_RRmPUBResXuWuw
I'm thinking it likely makes sense to either edit the issue description in place or to always have rustbot put in a first comment on threads like RFCs and MCPs where this might get invoked.
@simulacrum (what?)
In the future rustbot will likely be leaving the highfive "hey thanks" PR thread starter comments as well, so those can be used too
oh
I agree
I was going to suggest that but I forgot
This ties in with the "@rustbot note" thing I suggested
Yep
https://github.com/rust-lang/triagebot/issues/1427
I like the idea, btw, of having an initial comment on any PR where rustbot can be used
although we'd want to customize the descriptions
but i'd be a nice "signal" to help remember, too,Â and a kind of explanation

e.g., "rustbot is monitoring this thread. You can use "rustbot note" to add summary comments. If you are a team member, you can use "rustbot merge|close|stabilize" to kick off a decision process" things like that
we probably don't have to say that second part, since team membres kn ow
I think it's always nice to have a link to useful docs directly inline. I know I always need to hunt down crater's bot docs for example.
Yes
Another thought I just had: instead of "rustbot merge", maybe "rustbot approve"
or "accept"
I'm thinking about what you said @simulacrum about nomination, I think I realize the conection is even broader now:
e.g., we have been saying that we want to encourage folks who are nominating to be asking a concrete question
in some cases, I think that queston won't have yes/no form, but when it does, why not allow them to kick off a "decision"?
this is probably what you meant but I'm catching up

I think it's close to it -- definitely making nominations more transactional is good. I also want to identify a way for us to remove a label or otherwise indicate "handled" prior to someone posting a response from meeting discussion.

As I think about this, it might be a good use for the "not lang member takes action" feature -- particularly, e.g., if I'm coming out of a triage meeting I frequently write a summary on some issue or PR of what was discussed. It'd be nice if I could say something like rustbot discussed @rust-lang/lang [...summary...] and that automatically checks boxes for T-lang on the most recent question, or so.
yes, interesting
I feel like there's a "rustbot tenet" underlying this of "rust team members are trustworthy" :)
or "don't solve social problems with technical sol'ns"
Maybe we'd want something like discussed in-meeting, though, and that doesn't "check boxes" but adds a new participant to the list "Meeting 2021-07-21" and represents their feeling as merge

that way it is clear that individuals did not necessarily agree, but since the decision is reversible, this lets things go forward. OTOH, it is easy (and not a reversal) for someone not in attendance or who had different thoughts to register dissent/hold/etc

I at least wanted the ability to say like

rustbot merge foo bar baz

with the names of the people in the meeting, although that is probably fairly tedious to get right.
Yeah, and may not quite represent their opinions -- maybe just letting whoever is writing the summary (and as such is implicitly trusted) own the merge/close recommendation makes sense

I think if people aren't happy with the summary coming out of a meeting, it's easy for them to say @rustbot hold and "I want to think about this more, I don't know that I agree with the consensus from the meeting".
Right, but it likely makes sense for that to be seen as a transition from (nothing) -> hold, not agree -> hold. May be minor.

@simulacrum That's fair. In practice, I've noticed we don't often do the "check boxes for people who were in the meeting" thing, and I'd much rather have people check their own "boxes" by posting a comment.
